module.p: grunnan small number/group is a masculine diminutive generic quantity noun, derived from grunn number, group. Dictionaries list the genitive singular grunnain and the plural grunnanan.

In terms of the stuff being quantified, grunnan generally works like other generic quantity nouns, apart from the fact that it can only be followed by a plural count noun –
When the stuff being quantified is new information, it is usually expressed as a noun modifier/specifier of grunnan eg.
Tha grunnan chon aig Màiri. Mary has quite a few dogs.
td. 54
When the stuff being quantified is already known, it is usually introduced by the partitive preposition de of governing a specified (ie. ‘definite’) noun eg.
Cheannaich Màiri grunnan de mo choin. Mary bought quite a few of my dogs.
Bha grunnan de ar luchd-leughaidh an dùil, nuair a nochd an àireamh mu dheireadh de Ghairm, gu robh sin a’ strì ri buidheann shònraichte, no duine sònraichte, a chur do ’n Phàrlamaid, agus bha wèireichean an telefon gu math teth, uair no dhà, an déidh dhuinn tighinn o ’n chlò. Thog iad ceàrr sinn. [...]
Some of our readers were expecting [?], when the last issue of Gairm appeared, that that was striving for a particular group [party?], or a particular person, to send to the Parliament, and the telephone wires were pretty hot, for an hour or two [once or twice?], after we came from the printers. They misunderstood us. [...] td. 9, ‘Air An Spiris’
When the stuff being quantified is already known, and has just been referred to, or can be inferred, grunnan can occur on its own eg.
Tha grunnan aig Màiri. Mary has quite a few.
td. 55
Alternatively, grunnan can be followed by one of the de prepositional pronouns eg.
Tha grunnan dhiubh aig Màiri. Mary has quite a few of them.
td.

However, there is some variation in usage to be found here.
Bha grunnan de ar luchd-leughaidh an dùil, nuair a nochd an àireamh mu dheireadh de Ghairm, gu robh sin a’ strì ri buidheann shònraichte, no duine sònraichte, a chur do ’n Phàrlamaid, agus bha wèireichean an telefon gu math teth, uair no dhà, an déidh dhuinn tighinn o ’n chlò. Thog iad ceàrr sinn.
Some of our readers were expecting [?], when the last issue of Gairm appeared, that that was striving for a particular group [party?], or a particular person, to send to the Parliament, and the telephone wires were pretty hot, for an hour or two [once or twice?], after we came from the printers. They misunderstood us. td. 9, ‘Air an Spiris’
